children.subject:
Leaving the student answer open in case someone has more nuclear eng experience.

If you haven't already, you should read through @12406 as it may answer many of your questions. It is not a lab based course and overall pretty conceptual. Since it doesn't have a lab component, it wouldn't be affected much by the online situation, I'd expect lectures, office hours, and discussions to be on Zoom.

Although I haven't taken the nuclear engineering imaging course, based on the course description it seems to be a more physics-based course (particle physics approach, including unfolding methods). EEC145B takes a systems and mathematical approach.

history.content:
Hello! I havent taken a nuc eng class in over a year, but I was interested in taking ee 145b: medical imaging signals and systems

I have taken ee120, and im focusing more on robotics, but I have a spare class slot and I would like to take something interesting. 

What is this class like? What is professor Steven Conolly's teaching style like? Is this course lab based? What is the focus of this course? How will it work with the online situation? How does this course compare with the nuclear eng imaging courses? 

Thanks!
history.subject: ee145b vs comparable nuc eng courses?
